Piacere!
Ascoltiamo
1 Listen to the conversation. 01 0 Which of the following are used to address women? signore signorina signora
2 Listen again and then split into small groups to read the dialogue. 01 0
In Italy we shake hands during for- mal introductions. We say piacere (‘pleased to meet you’), or men can say molto lieto and women molto lieta.
Angelo Foi: Buongiorno! Lei è il signor …? Piero Volta: Sono Piero Volta. Buongiorno, molto lieto. Angelo Foi: Buongiorno. Lei è la signora Bianchi? Lara Martina: No, mi chiamo Lara Martina. Laura Bianchi: Laura Bianchi sono io, piacere. Angelo Foi: E la signorina Giorgia Fasani, è Lei? Giorgia Fasani: Sì, salve. We can also simply say Buongior- no/Buonasera! or Buongiorno/ Giochiamo Buonasera, signore/signora!
3 Gioco dei saluti. Take it in turns to say your name or surname; your classmates will respond with a greeting.
Sono Paolo Conti.
Mi chiamo Carla.
Buongiorno, signor Conti. Ciao, Carla.

Arrivederci! is a modern and easy to follow multimedia language course aimed at students with no previous knowledge of the Italian language. Thanks to slow, gradual progression Arrivederci! is also suited to students who have never studied a foreign language before. The course consists of three books that prepare students, respectively, for levels A1, A2 and B1/B1+ of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.
Arrivederci! 1 for English speakers consists of: l a Student’s book, organized in 12 teaching units l a Workbook l a DVD Video (version PAL - PC/MAC compatible), including episodes of a sit-com and authentic interviews for each unit (the video activities are available on our website: www.edilingua.it) l an Audio CD, sia in versione “naturale” che in versione “rallentata” (available on our website)
Arrivederci! 1 is completed by:
Interactive glossary in 10 languages IWB (free app) Interactive Workbook Interactive Whiteboard Software
